definition: Paekche or Baekje (18 BC-660 AD), one of the Korean Three Kingdoms
surname Bai
hundred/numerous/all kinds of
to cross a river/to aid or relieve/to be of help
only used in 濟濟|济济[ji3 ji3]
used in place names associated with the Ji River 濟水|济水[Ji3 Shui3]/surname Ji

sentences.english: The drifting people of Baekje are precisely produces under this historical perspective.
sentences.chinese: 百济遗民正是在此历史背景下出现的。

sentences.english: The second chapter elaborates the Baekje drifting people related to the historical background.
sentences.chinese: 第二章论述百济遗民相关的历史背景。

sentences.english: This chapter also describes the integration of the situation of Baekje drifting people in the Tang Dynasty and Japan.
sentences.chinese: 本章还阐述了百济遗民在唐朝和日本的融合状况。

sentences.english: Chapter IV focuses primarily on the inflow of Baekje drifting people against the resettlement policies.
sentences.chinese: 第四章主要阐述了各流入地对百济遗民的安置政策。

sentences.english: A huge number of Baekje drifting people come into different areas.
sentences.chinese: 数量庞大的百济遗民产生后，流入不同区域。

definition: Goguryeo (37 BC-668 AD), one of the Korean Three Kingdoms

Silla, Korean kingdom 57 BC-935 AD/one of the Korean Three Kingdoms from 1st century AD, defeating its rivals Paikche 百濟|百济[Bai3 ji4] and Koguryo 高句麗|高句丽[Gao1 gou1 li2] around 660 in alliance with Tang China/unified Silla 658-935
Korean Goryeo dynasty, 918-1392/Korea, esp. in context of art and culture
Tuyuhun, a Xianbei 鮮卑|鲜卑 nomadic people/a state in Qinhai in 4th-7th century AD
variant of 高句麗|高句丽[Gao1 gou1 li2]
Huihu, Tang dynasty name of ethnic group corresponding to modern Uighur 維吾爾|维吾尔[Wei2 wu2 er3]
Turkic ethnic group
Qidan or Khitan, ethnic group in ancient China, a branch of the Eastern Hu people inhabiting the valley of the Xar Murun River in the upper reaches of the Liao River 遼河|辽河[Liao2 He2]
Pu'yo, Korean Buyeo (c. 200 BC-494 AD), ancient kingdom in northeast frontier region of China
Yi Seong-gye (1335-1408), founder and first king of Korean Yi dynasty (1392-1910)
Japanese army (derog.) (old)
Tubo or Tufan, old name for Tibet/the Tibetan Tubo dynasty 7th-11th century AD/also pr. [Tu3 fan1]
Ryūkyū kingdom 1429-1879 (on modern Okinawa)
Nanzhao kingdom 738-937 in southwest China and southeast Asia
Xianbei or Xianbi, group of northern nomadic peoples
former southernmost province of the Chinese Empire, now northern Vietnam
